text: uh hi everyone nuthini start tano here
the internet's busiest
music nerd
and it's time for a review of the new
chris
stapleton album starting over this is
the newest and fourth full-length album
from one of the strongest
vocalists in country music today mr
chris
stapleton i've been anticipating big
things from chris
ever since i heard the impressive array
of performances he laid down
on from room volumes one and two back in
and i think starting over is the
improvements on
songwriting versatility and also
storytelling that he really needed to
propel his sound forward
now don't judge a book purely by its
cover because i know from the outside
this record doesn't look like much
the title and artist on this thing being
written out in what looks like pen
can be kind of deceptive you might even
go into this thing thinking am i going
to hear a bunch of
demos or b-sides or raw unmastered stuff
but starting over is quite the opposite
it is 14
perfectly crafted studio recordings that
strike an impeccable balance between
sounding clean
and clear while also very rustic and
pure
view the cover on this thing less as a
lack of effort and more as
maybe a clean possibly even stapleton
reintroducing himself to a degree
as some of the tracks here are so fiery
and refreshing
he sounds like a totally new artist
because over the past few years he's
really deepened his capacity to write
songs that are heartening
heartbreaking enraging and even fun the
whole thing kicks off with the title
track which is a low-key acoustic ballad
that really eases you
into the album the lyrics might come off
a little cliche with stapleton making
references to
roads and lucky pennies and four-leaf
clovers and things getting better but
it's actually a really inspired song
about sticking through the tougher times
in a relationship to reach a better
tomorrow the hook on this thing is
irresistibly cute with a beautiful rush
of heavily strummed cords and background
vocals
it's a great tune but chris's vocal
prowess isn't on full display yet we get
a much
better sense of that on devil made me
think twice next
which is a slick piece of country blues
this is most likely a
city slicker ass comparison but to me it
felt like a mix of
zz top some dire straights but
way more rustic and whiskey soaked the
slinky
fluid rhythm guitars on this track set a
great pace for this
swaying groove meanwhile stapleton is
hitting us with that
rasp that twang that range
that vocal heat really making me feel
every temptation he's singing about
trying to be on the good path but the
devil as it were straying him off of
that
then we have the even more hard-hitting
cold which is a somber string-backed
slow burner
essentially about putting a relationship
on pause and it is easily one of the
best
tunes i've heard this year in terms of
songwriting and performance like
god damn those vocals on the hook
gold honestly this thing deserves about
a dozen different cover versions
the passionate guitar solo on the bridge
is killer and the strings getting
heavier and heavier too
as the song progresses along fantastic
when i'm with you is a pretty typical
piece of tear in your beer country
very subtle instrumentation three four
time swirling and faint electric guitar
it's sweet while it's on but i can't
help but feel like
the mood of the instrumental isn't quite
meeting the
lovey-dovey lyrics the sudden ending of
the song feels like really having the
rug
pulled out from under me too it's uh
easily one of the bigger duds here
but then things pick up once again with
arkansas which is an
ass kicking piece of country rock with
punchy beats driving rifts and
stapleton's deliciously coarse
lead vocals it actually makes me want to
go to arkansas
ahem never mind the following joy of my
life is a cover of the god
john fogarty and while it is a damn good
tune i think
instrumentally chris and his
collaborators play it's so straight
that uh the end result is a little bland
which is a shame because
again it is a good tune but then the
track hillbilly blood breaches almost
into progressive territory with its
oddly tense chord changes on the intro
and the way the instrumentation
progressively gets
more and more heavy and thick as the
song moves along
also there's something to be said for
stapleton's odd lyrical mysticism around
hill billy blood talking about his
hillbilly background as if it's more of
a
i guess a biological destiny than it is
a lifestyle
weird flex but okay meanwhile maggie's
song is a painfully
cute track about a dog
a dog he found in a shopping cart when
it was a puppy and then she became a
part of his family and
it's just filled with endearing lyrics
about her life
her personality the way she grew into
the family
her passing it's so sweet i want to cry
and i want to die
then we have another of many extreme
contrasts across the track list
with whiskey sunrise which is a
profoundly depressing
and pained ballad about crying and
also drinking yourself to sleep and
eventually waking up in an absolutely
terrible state melodically parts of the
song sound
almost like a renovated version of the
house of the rising
sun which is not a bad thing i mean it's
a great folk song and if you're gonna
rip off an idea make it a good one
now past this point the tracklist hits
us with not one but
two guy clark covers really crossing
over into that
outlaw country territory here and i do
like some outlaw country he pulls
through with a very groovy version of
worry be gone
slightly changing the lyrics to make the
song about smoking weed
then with old friends stapleton proves
he can pull off very nicely one of those
classic talk sung ballads that are
very melodramatic in narrative and then
from here we move on to a
pretty strong ending for the record too
we have
the intense watch you burn
a song that is literally about that las
vegas shooting from a while back where
he calls the shooter out as being
cowardly and destined for an eternity of
burning in hell but between that
sinister instrumentation and the angry
groove
and the fact that stapleton's vocals are
just
seething they're just so potent with
rage definitely one of the heaviest
moments on the project
you should probably leave as one of the

one of the
roughest emotionally in part it does

heartbreaking track too about
essentially the pain to continue this
love to continue this relationship or to

great that uh to continue on will just
be
too much so might as well just cut
things off right here
and the way chris explains this very
tough decision in his lyrics is just
absolutely
uh earth-shattering you know heartbreak
is such a common and a cliched thing for

about so when one comes along and
translates it in a way where it comes
off so
intense that it's like hearing that

uh that's something then the closer

that
i'm parting with you we're breaking up

it's a pretty decent length too it is

it's hit after hit it's robust as well

it is easily one of the best records

i've heard this decade once everything
